hook: Microsoft’s iPod-era rival with Wi-Fi sharing and the Zune Pass subscription.
summary: Microsoft's digital media player ecosystem—hardware, software, and music store—launched in 2006 and was fully discontinued by 2012. Despite a well-liked UI and the Zune HD, it couldn’t overcome iPod/iTunes dominance and the shift to smartphones.
overview_md: **Zune** was Microsoft’s end-to-end music platform—portable players, the Zune desktop app, Marketplace, and the **Zune Pass** subscription. It introduced Wi-Fi track sharing and a distinctive, typography-forward UI. Later, the **Zune HD** earned strong reviews, but the iPod/iTunes lead and the rapid move to smartphones limited adoption. Hardware and brand were sunset by **2012**, and services were folded into Xbox/Groove before being retired.

timeline.text: Zune 30 launches with Wi-Fi sharing and Zune Marketplace.
Second-gen HDD (80/120) and flash models (4/8/16) ship; Zune Pass subscription gains attention.
Zune HD debuts with OLED display and refined touch UI.
Zune hardware/brand discontinued; services transition toward Xbox Music (later Groove).
